metadata.titleEn: Full-band spectral measurements of typical land cover types in China
metadata.description: The full-spectrum spectral measurements were conducted over 8 land cover types, including four vegetation types (i.e., forests (larch), shrubs, grasses and crops (maize)), two soil types (i.e., ordinary soil and frozen soil), snow, and cement road. Three spectrometer types were utilized to assemble the data records, namely the reflectance measurement from visible to shortwave infrared region (solar reflectance spectra), the emissivity measurement in the thermal infrared region (thermal emission spectra), and the microwave radiation measurement in the microwave region (microwave radiation). They were measured synchronously with ASD/SVC reflectance spectrometer, 102F/BOMAN emissivity meter, and microwave radiometers (RPG/JYRS). Associated with the spectra, the parameters describing the targets’ properties such as the object type, observed time, location, the solar and sensor geometry, satellite images as well as the observed instrument and contributions of units, were simultaneously recorded as the auxiliary information to describe the spectral measurement scene. The satellite pixel spectra (i.e., 10 m sentinel-OLI reflectance and 500 m MODIS reflectance) corresponding to the measured site was also extracted. This spectra library aids particularly the development of the modeling ，can also support further research on cross-spectrum domains underlying mechanisms, i.e. the physical radiative transfer processes, and the retrieval of surface biophysical and biochemical parameters. They can serve as a reference truth for satellite observations in validation. The full-spectrum spectra provide more useful information for characterizing the spectral endmembers of remote sensing models, thus support more accurate identification and classification of surface type.
metadata.instructions: This dataset includes 11 full-spectrum data records. Each full-spectrum spectra data record was organized in a folder named as “AAAA_BBBB_CCCC_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS_XXXX”. The “AAAA” were set as “spec, respectively. The “BBBB_CCCC” means the land cover and the object name. The “YYYYMMDDHHMMSS” shows the measured time. The core files of the full-spectrum include the combination data of reflectance, emissivity, microwave bright temperature, metadata files, and the satellite data. The data file was processed as TXT format and the metadata file was set as XML format. The satellite data and the quick view image were set as Tiff and JPEG format, respectively. As for the name of each spectral data, the file name is recorded as “AAAA_BBBB_CCCC_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS_XXXX”, where the “XXXX” shows the file type, “A000” means the data file, and “B000” means the auxiliary file of XML. The “AAAA” represents the spectral types, where “refl”, “emis”, and “mwra” denote the reflectance, emissivity, and microwave emissivity, respectively. And the “pixel”, “img”, and “view” represent the satellite pixel spectral, the satellite image, and the quick-view image, respectively. Regarding the name of the metadata, “AAAA” was set as “comp” and “pixel” . “comp”refer to the scene information of the spectra，and “pixel” indicates the information of satellite pixel spectra.

background: Field-measured spectra are critical for remote sensing physical modelling, retrieval of structural, biophysical, and biochemical parameters, and other practical applications. To the best of our knowledge, this library is unique in simultaneously providing full-band, multi-angle, multi-scale spectral measurements of the main surface elements of China covering a large spatial extent over a 10-year period.
research objective: In this paper, we present the full-wave band, multi-angle, multi-scale, and temporal dynamic spectral library dubbed Ground Object Spectral Library (GOSPEL).
challenges: However, there are several limitations to the exiting libraries. First, they provide spectra in shortwave, infrared, or microwave domains separately. This discontinuity does not meet the requirements for developing a unified spectral-domain radiative transfer model and its associated applications. Second, they rarely measure (and release) anisotropic spectra across different spectral domains. Nevertheless, apparent anisotropy exists in the surface reflectivity in the VNIR-SWIR spectral domain (e.g., bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF)), emissivity in the TIR spectral domain (e.g., directional bright temperature), and reflectivity or emissivity in the microwave spectral domains (e.g., directional microwave radiation). Ignoring the directionality of satellite observations may lead to large errors in the retrieval of remote sensing radiation and vegetation structure variables. Therefore, the multi-angular spectra are a pressing need to advance the estimation of surface energy budget and modeling of land surface processes. Third, there is a lack of multiscale spectra measurements (e.g., leaf and canopy spectra), which hinders the understanding of cross-scale physical radiative transfer and associated ecological processes. Hence, the collection of multiscale spectra is much needed to help improve the understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes from individual leaves to canopies and even ecosystems and promote the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes (e.g., upscaling plant function traits). Furthermore, the temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation are insufficient. Given the fact that the vegetation dynamics are crucial for modeling land cover change and plant phenology as well as its feedback to climate change, vegetation spectra across different growth stages need to be further supplemented in order to improve the monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use change, and surface phenology in general.
methods: We present a library of field spectra, which includes (1) portable field spectroradiometer measurements of vegetation, soil, and snow in the full-wave band, (2) multi-angle spectra measurements of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow with consideration of the anisotropic reflectance of land surface, (3) multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy of different vegetation cover surfaces, and (4) continuous reflectance spectra time-series data revealing vegetation growth dynamics of maize, rice, wheat, rape, grassland, and so on. Furthermore, the 101 by 101 satellite pixels of Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance centered around the field site were extracted, providing a vital linkage between ground measurements and satellite observations.
dataset: We present a library of field spectra, which includes (1) portable field spectroradiometer measurements of vegetation, soil, and snow in the full-wave band, (2) multi-angle spectra measurements of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow with consideration of the anisotropic reflectance of land surface, (3) multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy of different vegetation cover surfaces, and (4) continuous reflectance spectra time-series data revealing vegetation growth dynamics of maize, rice, wheat, rape, grassland, and so on.
findings: We believe that this spectral library will undoubtedly advance the development of the modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology, support further research on cross-scale ecological processes and underlying mechanisms, the quantification of the geometric effects of solar and sensor on the physical radiative transfer processes, and the retrieval of surface biophysical and biochemical parameters. Moreover, it can serve as the ground-truth information for validation of satellite spectral measurements.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that captures the multi-angle spectral measurements of land surfaces in diverse spectral domains?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for capturing multi-angle spectral measurements involves using portable field spectroradiometers to measure the anisotropic reflectance of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow across full-wave bands, while considering the directional properties of the land surface.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that integrates both ground-based spectral measurements and satellite observations for a comprehensive analysis?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is one that includes portable field spectroradiometer measurements of vegetation, soil, and snow, along with the extraction of satellite pixels from Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance, providing a linkage between ground measurements and satellite data.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how temporal dynamic spectra are used to monitor vegetation growth stages?
Example.Answer: Temporal dynamic spectra are used to monitor vegetation growth stages by providing continuous reflectance spectra time-series data that reveal the growth dynamics of various vegetation types such as maize, rice, wheat, rape, and grassland.

Feature Specification.Answer: full-wave band spectral data, anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, spectra measurements at different scales, continuous reflectance spectra time-series data

Feature Specification.Question: What are some challenges in collecting and utilizing spectral data across different spectral domains for remote sensing?
Feature Specification.Answer: discontinuity of spectra, anisotropic spectral measurements, difficulty of obtaining multiscale spectra, capturing temporal dynamic spectra

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics are essential for a dataset that aims to support the modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology?
Feature Specification.Answer: full-wave band spectral measurements, multi-angle and multi-scale spectra, continuous time-series data of vegetation reflectance

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'full-wave band spectra' in the context of field spectra measurements?
Definition.Answer: Full-wave band spectra refer to the comprehensive measurement of reflectance and emissivity across various spectral domains, including the visible, near-infrared, shortwave infrared, thermal infrared, and microwave spectral domains, as captured by portable field spectroradiometers and related instruments.

Definition.Question: What constitutes 'multi-scale spectra measurements' when assessing vegetation cover surfaces?
Definition.Answer: Multi-scale spectra measurements refer to collecting spectral data at varying spatial scales, such as individual leaves and entire plant canopies, to understand cross-scale radiative transfer processes and the scaling effects on ecological processes, including plant functional traits and surface energy budgets.

Comparison.Question: How do continuous reflectance spectra time-series data compare to static spectral measurements in terms of their utility for monitoring vegetation growth dynamics and modeling land cover change?
Comparison.Answer: Continuous reflectance spectra time-series data offer dynamic insights into vegetation growth stages and phenological changes, providing a temporal dimension that static spectral measurements lack. This dynamic aspect is crucial for accurate modeling of land cover change and understanding plant phenology, allowing for the observation of growth patterns and responses to environmental changes over time. Static measurements, while useful for snapshot analyses, do not capture temporal variability essential for these applications.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological approaches are employed to ensure the accuracy and consistency of full-wave band spectral measurements across different land cover types?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodology involves the use of portable field spectroradiometer measurements, multi-angle spectral measurements considering anisotropic reflectance, and multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy. Additionally, continuous reflectance spectra time-series data and linkage with satellite data are utilized to ensure accuracy and consistency.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for multi-angle spectral measurements in data collection methods within this field?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a need for multi-angle spectral measurements due to the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, which affects the retrieval of remote sensing radiation and vegetation structure variables. Ignoring the directionality of satellite observations can lead to large errors in these retrievals.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a demand for multiscale spectral measurements when collecting data in this domain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The demand for multiscale spectral measurements arises from the need to understand cross-scale physical radiative transfer and associated ecological processes. The lack of such data hinders the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes and the improvement of upscaling plant function traits from individual leaves to canopies and ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of continuous reflectance spectra time-series data for vegetation in this field?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The necessity for continuous reflectance spectra time-series data is driven by the importance of vegetation dynamics for modeling land cover change, plant phenology, and their feedback to climate change. Supplementing vegetation spectra across different growth stages enhances the monitoring and modeling of land cover, land use change, and surface phenology.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of continuous reflectance spectra time-series data impact the monitoring and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics and phenology?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of continuous reflectance spectra time-series data can significantly improve the monitoring and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics and phenology by providing detailed insights into vegetation changes across different growth stages, which is crucial for understanding land cover changes and plant responses to climate change.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences could arise from utilizing multi-scale spectra measurements for understanding cross-scale ecological processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multi-scale spectra measurements can advance the understanding of cross-scale ecological processes by facilitating the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes, such as upscaling plant function traits, and improving the comprehension of radiative transfer processes from individual leaves to canopies and ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of creating a dataset that includes full-wave band, multi-angle, and multi-scale spectral measurements across different land cover types in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to provide a comprehensive spectral library that supports remote sensing physical modeling, retrieval of structural, biophysical, and biochemical parameters, and other practical applications. This dataset addresses the need for continuity in spectral data across different domains and offers a resource for advanced estimation of surface energy budgets and modeling of land surface processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to include multi-angle and multi-scale spectra measurements in the context of studying land surface processes and ecological dynamics?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including multi-angle and multi-scale spectra measurements is crucial because it addresses the anisotropic nature of surface reflectivity and the need to understand cross-scale radiative transfer processes. This approach helps improve the understanding of scaling effects on ecological processes and the modeling of land cover change, vegetation phenology, and surface energy budgets.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the integration of temporal dynamic spectra into datasets for monitoring vegetation growth and land cover changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of temporal dynamic spectra is motivated by the necessity to capture vegetation dynamics across different growth stages. This information is vital for improving the monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use changes, as well as understanding vegetation phenology and its feedback to climate change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques are employed to ensure the accuracy and consistency of full-band spectral measurements across different land cover types?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The full-band spectral measurements are ensured through the use of portable field spectroradiometer measurements, multi-angle spectra measurements with consideration of anisotropic reflectance, and multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy. Additionally, continuous reflectance spectra time-series data are used to track vegetation growth dynamics, ensuring accuracy and consistency across different land cover types.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the process of linking ground spectral measurements to satellite observations executed in this domain?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The linkage between ground spectral measurements and satellite observations is established by extracting 101 by 101 satellite pixels of Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance centered around the field site. This provides a crucial connection between detailed field measurements and broader satellite data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to preprocess the spectral data for the removal of atmospheric water vapor anomalies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To preprocess the spectral data, a least squares polynomial fitting algorithm is applied to remove atmospheric water vapor anomalies. This is followed by the use of a piecewise linear interpolation function to interpolate the spectral curve to a 1nm spectral resolution, resulting in a smooth and continuous spectral curve.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of multi-angle and multiscale spectral measurements to improve the modeling of land surface radiative processes?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multi-angle and multiscale spectral measurements is enabled by the use of portable field spectroradiometers, which measure the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, and the collection of spectra from different vegetation surfaces at both leaf and canopy scales. This approach helps improve the understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes and supports the modeling of land surface processes.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in spectroradiometer instruments facilitate the acquisition of full-band spectral data across various land cover types?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements in spectroradiometer instruments, such as those capable of measuring visible, infrared, and microwave spectra, facilitate the acquisition of full-band spectral data across various land cover types. These instruments allow for comprehensive field spectra collection of vegetation, soil, and snow, providing critical data for remote sensing physical modeling and parameter retrieval.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the collection of continuous reflectance spectra time-series data support the monitoring and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of continuous reflectance spectra time-series data supports the monitoring and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics by revealing temporal changes in vegetation, such as maize, rice, wheat, and grassland. This data is crucial for understanding land cover change, plant phenology, and their feedback to climate change, thereby enhancing monitoring and modeling efforts.

Expectation.Question: Why is there an expectation for continuous reflectance spectra time-series data to significantly aid in the understanding of vegetation growth dynamics?
Expectation.Answer: Continuous reflectance spectra time-series data reveal the dynamics of vegetation growth across different stages, which are crucial for improving monitoring and modeling of land cover changes, plant phenology, and their feedback to climate change.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing spectral libraries be insufficient for advancing the modeling of plant growth and ecological processes?
Expectation.Answer: Existing spectral libraries often lack comprehensive coverage across spectral domains, do not account for anisotropic spectral measurements, and fail to provide multi-scale data, which are all necessary for a unified spectral-domain radiative transfer model and understanding of ecological processes at various scales.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of multi-angle and multi-scale spectral measurements in capturing anisotropy and cross-scale radiative transfer processes in remote sensing?
Judgmental.Answer: The multi-angle and multi-scale spectral measurements are effective in capturing anisotropy and cross-scale radiative transfer processes as they address the limitations of existing libraries. By providing anisotropic spectra across spectral domains and multiscale spectra measurements, they help improve the understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes from individual leaves to canopies and ecosystems, thus advancing the estimation of surface energy budget and modeling land surface processes.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the primary challenges faced when collecting continuous reflectance spectra time-series data for vegetation growth dynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: One primary challenge in collecting continuous reflectance spectra time-series data for vegetation growth dynamics is the insufficiency of temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation. This insufficiency can impact modeling land cover change and plant phenology, as well as understanding the feedback to climate change. Ensuring comprehensive temporal coverage across different growth stages is crucial for improving monitoring and modeling efforts.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the potential benefits of linking satellite pixels with ground measurements in spectral studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Linking satellite pixels with ground measurements can significantly enhance spectral studies by providing a vital linkage between ground measurements and satellite observations. This connection is crucial for validating satellite spectral measurements and supports the modeling of plant growth, vegetation phenology, and the retrieval of surface biophysical and biochemical parameters. Such integration offers a more comprehensive understanding of ecological processes and scaling effects.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how field-measured spectra contribute to remote sensing applications or modeling land surface processes.
Assertion.Answer: Field-measured spectra are critical for remote sensing physical modeling, retrieval of structural, biophysical, and biochemical parameters. They provide essential data for developing unified spectral-domain radiative transfer models and enable the estimation of surface energy budgets and modeling of land surface processes by incorporating multi-angle, multi-scale, and temporal dynamic spectral data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the methods used to ensure that field spectra measurements align with satellite data.
Assertion.Answer: Methods involve extracting satellite pixels of Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance centered around field sites, providing vital linkage between ground measurements and satellite observations. This helps in validating satellite spectral measurements and understanding the geometric effects of solar and sensor interactions on radiative transfer processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the techniques used in collecting full-band spectral data of different land cover types in China and how these techniques address the challenges of discontinuity across spectral domains.
Request/Directive.Answer: The techniques involve using portable field spectroradiometers to measure full-wave band spectra of vegetation, soil, and snow. Multi-angle and multi-scale spectral measurements are performed, considering anisotropic reflectance. Additionally, continuous reflectance spectra time-series data are collected to capture vegetation growth dynamics, and satellite pixel data are integrated to link ground and satellite measurements. These approaches help address the discontinuity across spectral domains by providing comprehensive, unified spectra and considering anisotropic and multi-scale characteristics.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential advantages of integrating continuous reflectance spectra time-series data with satellite observations for the monitoring and modeling of land cover change.
Request/Directive.Answer: Integrating continuous reflectance spectra time-series data with satellite observations provides a vital linkage between detailed ground measurements and broader satellite data. This integration allows for improved monitoring and modeling of land cover change, as it captures vegetation dynamics across growth stages, which are essential for understanding land cover changes, plant phenology, and feedback to climate change.
